key_title: Key to the species of Salix

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Salicaceae

source.author: Carr, G.W.
source.title: Salix
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: From: Carr, G.W. (1996). Salix. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves ovate, obovate, oblong, elliptic or suborbicular, less than 3 times as long as wide, apex obtuse or acute
Leaves linear, linear-lanceolate, or oblanceolate, more than 3 times as long as.wide; apex acute to acuminate

Leaves generally obovate, margins undulate or not; indumentum on underside of leaves rough to soft, grey, with or without rust-coloured hairs; plants male or female; twigs relatively slender, branches and twigs spreading to erect, crown typically wide

Leaves elliptic or elliptic-obovate, margins generally strongly undulate; indumentum on underside of leaves very soft, rust-coloured hairs absent, midrib on underside of leaves very densely long-pilose; plants male; twigs coarse, branches and twigs rigidly erect; crown rather narrow

At least some leaves opposite or subopposite, very shortly petiolate, becoming glabrous or almost so soon after expansion; many-stemmed shrubs; catkins appearing before leaves, catkin-scales purple-black except at base

All leaves alternate, short- to long-petiolate, glabrous or pubescent; single to few-stemmed shrubs or trees; catkins terminating short leafy lateral branches; catkin-scales wholly pale yellow or yellow-green
Trees, strongly weeping; outer branches, twigs and shoots long-pendulous, straight, curved or contorted-flexuose, leaves flat or contorted
Shrubs or trees, branches, twigs and shoots erect to spreading, straight or curved, not weeping; leaves flat
Outer branches, twigs, shoots and leaves strongly contorted-flexuose
Outer branches, twigs and shoots not contorted-flexuose; leaves flat

Catkins with short peduncle to 3 mm long, exclusively female, 0.6–2.8 cm long; ovaries shortly pyriform or ovoid, not tapering to apex; branches very long-pendulous and twigs and shoots vertically weeping in mature plants; leaves with pale green, subterete, non-glandular teeth to c. 0.8 mm long; young leaves nearly glabrous

Catkins with peduncle to 6 mm long, male, female or androgynous, female catkins to 4.6 cm long; ovaries flask-shaped, tapering to apex; branches twigs and shoots short- to long-pendulous, twigs and shoots vertically weeping or not in mature plants; leaves with at least some glandular or subglandular teeth to 0.25 mm (rarely to 1 mm) long; young leaves usually pubescent
Leaves distinctly and rather irregularly serrate, glabrous or thinly hairy when young; ovary glabrous or hairy, elongate, flask-shaped, usually much longer than catkin-scale
Leaves finely minutely serrate, pubescent or silky when young; ovaries shortly flask-shaped, not much longer than catkin-scale
Leaves linear-lanceolate, green on both sides, but somewhat paler beneath; bark very dark brown, becoming scaly at intermediate stages; male and female plants present; stamens 5 (rarely 4
Leaves lanceolate, strongly glaucous or glaucescent beneath; bark pale to dark brown, fissured but not scaly; male or female only, or male and female plants present; stamens 2 (rarely 3)
Multi-stemmed shrubs to 5 m high and wide; bark smooth, sometimes flaking; stipules persistent
Erect or spreading trees to 20 m high; bark ultimately deeply fissured, not flaking; stipules caducous
Leaves glossy-green above, at first nearly glabrous or, if appressed-sericeous, soon glabrous or nearly so on both surfaces; twigs moderately to very brittle at junction with branch

Leaves dull or only moderately glossy above, densely appressed-sericeous at first, persistently sericeous below, sericeous or glabrescent above; twigs not brittle at junction with stem; glandular teeth on leaf margins regularly spaced, minute
